item.title: Keeping things clean
item.author: Author
item.description: So far so good! We have an app displaying statistical distributions. A user can select the distribution and move sliders to change parameter values. The main problem is we now have a single python file with a few hundred lines of code. Not the end of the world, yet, but there are dozens of distributions we might want to add. Things could quickly get out of hand! Move functionality to a module What do we need to keep?

item.title: Building something useful
item.author: Author
item.description: We’re now ready to build something useful! The plan is to build an interactive app for displaying and exploring statistical distributions. Distribution selector Imports We are going to draw charts, use data frames, and interact with Scipy’s stats module, so first, starting from a blank slate, we need to import the following modules: import altair as alt import numpy as np import pandas as pd import streamlit as st import scipy.

item.title: Adding interactivity
item.author: Author
item.description: Notice how we did not have to write any boilerplate to get a working Streamlit app? Streamlit repeatedly re-runs the entire file app.py, so the entire app file is being looped over and over. This means you (as the app developer) do not have to handle any event loops or callbacks yourself. Too add something more interesting to the app, we could take a quick look at: the Streamlit getting started documentation.

item.title: A first app
item.author: Author
item.description: In this section we will create an empty GitHub repository, clone it, and create an extremely basic Streamlit app that we will be able to view in a web browser. The app will not do much at all, but once we have completed this checkpoint we will be set up with everything we need for the rest of the workshop. item.title: Prerequisites
item.author: Author
item.description: There are a small number of tools you need in order to create and deploy Streamlit apps. Software Python Streamlit is a Python package, and requires Python 3.6+. To verify you have an appropriate version of Python, run: python --version from a command line. If you see a Python 2 version then try python3 --version instead. Tip If you are installing Python on Windows, make sure you tick the “add to path” option when presented.
